entry.title: media/gpu/v4l2: wait for and produce |CAPTURE_queue_| decoded pics
entry.content:
This CL implements the (blocking) waiting for decoded pictures on

|CAPTURE_queue_|, extracting those decoded pictures, producing the

associated VideoFrames and recycling them when available. It

essentially completes the decoding part, albeit there might be

circumstances where the logic stalls.



Since the wait is blocking, it happens in a SequencedTaskRunner we

get from a pool. A convenience RearmCAPTUREQueueMonitoring() method

does the hop to WaitOnceForCAPTUREQueueEvent() with a callback to

TryAndDequeueCAPTUREQueueBuffers() when the event happens. Note that

the "wait" happens only once and is re-armed from the main thread,

which simplifies lifetime reasoning.



Only weird thing really is the specific VideoFrame handling needed

for V4L2_MEMORY_MMAP CAPTURE queue (i.e. MTK8173 Hana), where

there's some manual lifetime mgmt needed :-(



A new DecodeAndOutputAllFrames test case is added for verification,

and it passes on MT8173 Hana and QC7180 trogdor. Anecdotally, while

decoding, most queues are almost empty/full (encoded chunks/decoded

frames, respectively), pointing to the current queue mgmt as more

performant than what ToT does.



Tested on hana and trogdor via:

/usr/local/libexec/chrome-binary-tests/video_decode_accelerator_tests

/usr/local/share/tast/data_pushed/go.chromium.org/tast-tests/cros/local/bundles/cros/video/data/test-25fps.vp8

'--vmodule=*/media/gpu/v4l2/*=4'

--gtest_filter=*.DecodeAndOutputAllFrames

--enable-features=V4L2FlatStatefulVideoDecoder



(this decodes all frames but skips the Flush at the end because the

end-of-stream logic is not implemented).



Bug: b:279980150

Change-Id: Id6f1a2ed99b8662670372964a35b9b9b3cac4c22

Reviewed-on: https://chromium-review.googlesource.com/c/chromium/src/+/4676285

Reviewed-by: Hang Nguyen

Reviewed-by: Andres Calderon Jaramillo

Commit-Queue: Miguel Casas-Sanchez

Cr-Commit-Position: refs/heads/main@{#1171582}

entry.title: [BestEffortServiceWorker] Add dedicated LCP for eligible page loads
entry.content:
This CL adds new UMA

(NavigationToLargestContentfulPaint2.RaceNetworkRequestEligible) that

records LCP only when the ServiceWorker script is "eligible" for the

feature.



"eligible" doesn't mean that the feature is enabled. The feature is only

enabled when the user belongs to the experiment group, and SW script

hash matches the allowlist, which is passed as a feature param.



We'll have an analysis in counterfactual way: Collect the metrics for

both experiment/control groups with a bias of eligibility. Eligibility

and experiment groups are independent. This feature first checks the

eligibility (whether SW script hash matches our list of samples) and

then checks the feature is enabled.



This is achieved by adding a new enum to

ServiceWorkerFetchHandlerBypassOption, which is

`kRaceNetworkRequestHoldback`. This means the page load is eligible for

the feature, but actually RaceNetworkRequest is not dispatched.



This CL plumbs ServiceWorkerFetchHandlerBypassOption and provide the

info as one of a loading behavior, in order to let

ServiceWorkerPageLoadMetricsObserver know if the page load is eligible

for the RaceNetworkRequest.





Bug: 1420517

entry.title: Revert "sheriff: Disable ReportingServiceTest.ProcessReportingEndpointsHeaderPathAbsolute."
entry.content:
This reverts commit bbde40d0488d1933e20357fbd8fcee9cb3eaad5a.



Reason for revert: The flakiness in this test was almost certainly

caused by https://crbug.com/1344573, which caused random flake

in every test with a message loop that used a ScopedFeatureList.



The underlying issue has been fixed (or at least worked around),

and we shouldn't be leaving a random subset of tests that used

ScopedFeatureList disabled due to it.



Original change's description:

> sheriff: Disable ReportingServiceTest.ProcessReportingEndpointsHeaderPathAbsolute.

entry.title: LayoutNG: Store NGPhysicalBoxFragment RareData fields in a Vector
entry.content:
NGPhysicalBoxFragment::RareData was wasteful because we had to

allocate the whole RareData instance even if only one field was

necessary.



This CL makes non-GCed fields of RareData class storable in a Vector.

Also, this moves the RareData class to its own source files.



This CL should have no user-visible behavior changes.



Bug: 1353190,1454298

entry.title: Reduce flickering from unstable punctuation and capitalization
entry.content:
This CL reduces flickering of the caption text when Live Translate is

enabled by caching untranslated text without punctuation or

capitalization. This change makes the Live Translate look for identical

phrases with alternate punctuation or capitalization and if found, use

the previous variant. This helps reduce flicker caused by an unstable

comma or question mark that can continue to flicker even though multiple

new sentences have been added since those words were spoken.



Bug: 1426899

Change-Id: If00c1e8aff8faaffc5e903a51b9b133e1fd41869

Reviewed-on: https://chromium-review.googlesource.com/c/chromium/src/+/4692202

Commit-Queue: Evan Liu

Cr-Commit-Position: refs/heads/main@{#1171563}

entry.title: Added ScopedPause to suppress nudges and toasts
entry.content:
This CL added ScopedAnchoredNudgePause and ScopedToastPause to suppress

anchored nudges and toasts. It will prevent all the nudges or toasts

from showing up during its lifetime. If paused, all the nudges or toasts

that are currently showing will disappear immediately. If a nudge or a

toast is dismissed, they won't be shown again since they are triggered

by user interactions in time.



Bug: b:271480256, b:278096844

Change-Id: Ie393b8374e0084350311dd66ea8e276248be5725

entry.title: Revert "Disable flakily crashing network test"
entry.content:
This reverts commit 415a6be6381f56de652e8288198673ac8eb23ca8.



Reason for revert: The flakiness in this test was almost certainly

caused by https://crbug.com/1344573, which caused random flake

in every test with a message loop that used a ScopedFeatureList.



The underlying issue has been fixed (or at least worked around),

and we shouldn't be leaving a random subset of tests that used

ScopedFeatureList disabled due to it.

entry.title: Remove error handling in ParseExtensionPrinterSettings()
entry.content:
ParseExtensionPrinterSettings() receives its input dictionary from Print

Preview TS code, which is trusted code. As such, there is no need to

handle failures, as the trusted TS code should always generate valid

input.

entry.title: Replace Prerender2Holdback with PrerenderDSEHoldback + PreloadingConfig
entry.content:
This removes Prerender2Holdback, and introduces PrerenderDSEHoldback.

Holdback tests which previously relied on Prerender2Holdback now rely on

either PreloadingConfig or PrerenderDSEHoldback. (Note that DevTools

already is aware of PreloadingConfig, and it doesn't need to be aware of

PrerenderDSEHoldback, so some holdback-related code and tests are just

removed from the DevTools part of the codebase.)



See the linked bug for the motivation.



Bug: 1464173

entry.title: Make a service from image search
entry.content:
This CL elevates local images search to a service, which is a

wrapper around the AnnotationStorage. It allows us to keep a

global lock for the SQLite database and serve async calls.

entry.title: Add holdback_status_override to PrerenderAttributes
entry.content:
This allows code in //chrome (e.g., for DSE) to override the holdback

status. In this CL, it is always left as kUnspecified (except in the new

tests). In future CLs, we will set it to kHoldback, when the new DSE

holdback feature is enabled.

entry.title: AreUpdatesSuppressedNow and verify updates suppressed across days
entry.content:
This CL adds a `AreUpdatesSuppressedNow` helper method to the policy

manager, and adds tests to verify that updates are suppressed for

durations that span across to the next day.

entry.title: Mark DrawingBuffer's destruction_in_progress_ earlier.
entry.content:
Prior to the fix for Issue 1441633, DrawingBuffer::BeginDestruction

marked destruction_in_progress_ earlier, but still cleaned up the

allocated SharedImages for its ColorBuffers. It seems that

WebGLRenderingContext's destructor has become more expensive possibly

due to additional cleanup work for in-flight ColorBuffers, so restore

the old behavior, while still cleaning up the SharedImages associated

with these ColorBuffers.



Covered by the existing automated test for Issue 1441633.

entry.title: Support forwarding `--v=N` flag to device in adb_command_line.py
entry.content:
To enable verbose logging in Chromium, one can pass the arguments

`--enable-logging --v=3` (or some value other than 3). However on

Android, the adb_command_line.py script is interpreting `--v=3` as being

supplied to the script itself, rather than forwarding the argument to the device. This is caused by these calls:



```

// This includes a -v/--verbose flag

logging_common.AddLoggingArguments(parser)



// Attempts to interpret --v=3 as a logging argument

args, remote_args = parser.parse_known_args()

```



This change adds support for the "--" separator to explicitly distinguish

arguments which should be forwarded to the device.



Before this change:



```

// command fails

$ ./build/android/adb_chrome_public_command_line --enable-logging --v=3

usage: adb_command_line.py --name FILENAME [--device SERIAL] [flags...]



No flags: Prints existing command-line file.

Empty string: Deletes command-line file.

Otherwise: Writes command-line file.

adb_command_line.py: error: argument -v/--verbose: ignored explicit argument '3'

```



After this change:



```

$ ./build/android/adb_chrome_public_command_line -- --enable-logging --v=3

W 12:00:30.714 0.123s update_flags(XXXXXXXXXXXXXX) Your device (XXXXXXXXXXXXXX) is a user build; Chrome may or may not pick up your commandline flags. Check your "command_line_on_non_rooted_enabled" preference, or switch devices.

Wrote command line file. Current flags (in chrome-command-line):

XXXXXXXXXXXXXX (oriole-user 13 XXXX.XXXXXX.XXX XXXXXXX release-keys): --enable-logging --v=3

```



On device:



* Visit chrome://flags.

* Set "#enable-command-line-on-non-rooted-devices" to "Enabled".

* Restart Browser.

* Visit chrome://version.

* Observe the "Command Line:" starts with "_ --v=3 --enable-logging"



Change-Id: I91a41d13b47ab91b2286807c9208c4e592ec8159

Reviewed-on: https://chromium-review.googlesource.com/c/chromium/src/+/4691348

Reviewed-by: Benjamin Joyce (Ben)

Commit-Queue: Benjamin Joyce (Ben)

Cr-Commit-Position: refs/heads/main@{#1171514}

entry.title: AW: fix test batching logic for WebView multiprocess
entry.content:
WebView tests may run in 2 possible modes: single process or

multiprocess (Refer to the @OnlyRunIn annotation). Switching process

mode requires restarting the browser process though, and tests which

used @Batch will default to not restarting. This bug meant that we were

running each test case twice, however both runs were actually the same

process mode (either both runs used an in-process renderer or both used

an out-of-process renderer). This was not immediately obvious because

the kWebViewSandboxedRenderer flag was being toggled correctly,

however the flag toggle had no effect because it's only read during a

process restart.



This change fixes the problem by enforcing that single-process and

multiprocess tests will never share a batch. Even though this does not

change how many test cases we actually run, this fix the process mode

for 15% of test cases, effectively increasing our test coverage.



This will have a slight impact to webview_instrumentation_test_apk

runtime, because the number of batches increases from 29 to 55. This

doesn't change the number of tests though, so the total runtime will

only increase slightly.



Fixed: 1465680

Test: Manually verify single & multiprocess tests get different batches

Test: run_webview_instrumentation_test_apk

Change-Id: Id5748f880b6db168a43dd7adac94df3c293b262d

entry.title: [Service Workers] Allow fetches from workers to use auto-picked certs
entry.content:
Certain requests may require client certs to proceed. The default

behavior for this is to show the user a certificate picker, from which

they can select one. There is also an enterprise policy to allow for

auto-selecting certificates for different URLs.



We only want to show the certificate picker to the user if the request

is made by a web page (something that has a corresponding WebContents);

otherwise, the UI is alarming and confusing. Because of this, we

auto-cancel any client cert selection for requestors that don't have a

WebContents. However, this means that requests from service workers

will never succeed, even if the certificate for the request would have

been auto-selected by policy.



Fix this by instead allowing requests from service workers to check if

there is an auto-selected certificate, and using that if so. Otherwise,

we continue with the old flow of requiring a WebContents to select a

certificate.



Add an end-to-end browser test for the same.

entry.title: [scheduler] Remove TestTaskQueue in SequenceManager tests
entry.content:
(6/8) of TaskQueue lifetime refactor, which will make sequence manager

TaskQueue uniquely owned and a pure virtual interface implemented by

TaskQueueImpl.



This removes TestTaskQueue so tests access TaskQueue through a Handle

like in production. Some tests used a weak pointer to ensure task queue

reference counting worked as expected, but this isn't needed now since

TaskQueue is uniquely owned by the handle so tests are modified.



TaskQueue::AsWeakPtr() is also removed since it isn't used. This can be

added back if there's a use case, but WeakPtr is tricky

because a TaskQueue can change which thread it's bound to (see

crrev.com/c/4357175).

entry.title: Introduce MediaDeviceSaltDatabase and update service interface
entry.content:
This CL:

* Introduces MediaDeviceSaltDatabase, which is a new SQL-based storage

backend that stores a salt per storage key instead of a single global

salt.

* Updates the interface of MediaDeviceSaltService to introduce

new operations supported by MediaDeviceSaltDatabase.

* The callsites for data removal and enumerateDevices/getUserMedia have

been ported to the new service interface. Other callsites (extension

APIs) will be ported in follow-up CLs.

* Introduces two new features:

"MediaDeviceIdPartitioning", which uses MediaDeviceSaltDatabase to

store salts. If disabled, the global salt is the only persistent

salt and behavior is unchanged.

"MediaDeviceIdRandomSaltsPerStorageKey", which enables initializing

each new entry in the database with a random salt. If disabled,

new database entries are initialized with the global salt.

The idea is to first enable MediaDeviceIdPartitioning, which will

will allow existing persistent device IDs to continue to be valid

and will allow deletion of entries per time range. Resetting of

device IDs per origin/storage keys will not work in practice

because the global salt is still used to initialize database

entries.

After 2-3 releases MediaDeviceRandomSaltsPerStorageKey will be

enabled, which will allow resetting of device IDs per storage key.

* Enables the features (as a parameterized test option) in

WebRtcMediaDevicesInteractiveUITest, which is the main browser test

for device enumerations.

* Adds a new ChromeBrowsingDataRemoverDelegateMediaDeviceSaltTest with

the new features enabled.



Bug: 1410462

entry.title: nacl: Fix crash involving NaClHostMessageFilter.
entry.content:
The implementation of the NaClHostMessageFilter relies on the assumption

that the associated profile is not the "system profile". Currently,

NaClHostMessageFilter is created for all renderers including those

associated with the "system profile". This doesn't cause issues most of

the time because no IPC messages are received by the

NaClHostMessageFilter. However, if a compromised renderer sends certain

messages (e.g. OnLaunchNaCl) then this will result in a nullptr

dereference in the browser process.



This CL modifies ChromeContentBrowserClient so that it only creates a

NaClHostMessageFilter for non "system profile" profiles.

entry.title: [PhoneHub][Nudge] Add values to pref service to track nudge display
entry.content:
details.



Register and store these values in PrefService

1) A timestamp of when Phone Hub nudge has been shown

2) Count of how many times nudge has been shown

3) If there is user interaction with nudge

a) On hover: timestamp of when nudge was hovered

b) On click: timestamp of when nudge was clicked

4) Synced devices list from CryptAuth.



Also do not show nudge if within 24 hours or total appearances passes

3. Reset total appearances and timestamp if a new eligible phone is

synced.



Tested: Verified on DUT that:

1) Nudge will not be shown again if last shown time is within

the delay time (5 minutes in testing).

2) Nudge will not be shown again if nudge has been shown 3

times.

3) Added a new eligible phone to the account will reset values

and nudge will be shown again.

4) Added ineligible phone does not reset values. Nudge will

not be shown again.

Bug: b/267809132

entry.title: Fix PrinterSemanticCapsAndDefaults::Paper default printable area
entry.content:
When constructing a paper object, if the constructor which only provides

a paper size is used then that same size should also be used for the

printable area. Otherwise the empty printable area will cause mojom

verification to fail. This kind of failure condition is demonstrated

by PrintBackendMojomTraitsTest.TestPaperEmptyPrintableArea.



PrintBackendMojomTraitsTest.TestPaperCtors now demonstrates that it no

longer causes this condition to occur.

entry.title: arc/gio: Preserve the changes for default actions
entry.content:
This CL makes sure that the changes for default actions are preserved.

There are two types of actions. One is default action with action ID <=

kMaxDefaultActionID and is from json files. The other is user-added

action with ID > kMaxDefaultActionID and is saved in proto files. The

json file is not able to rewrite, so it needs to save changes of default

actions in the proto files. Since there is function for restoring

default actions, when loading mapping data, GIO always loads the josn

files first and then loading proto files.



For deleted default actions, they still need to keep in the

TouchInjector::actions() list to make sure that the deleted actions are

marked deleted in proto. For default actions, they are considered as

deleted when the input binding source is none. When deleting user-added

actions, they are removed from list directly.



For changing action type for default actions, save its original type to

make sure the changes will write to proto.



Other changes related:

- Use binary search to find the smallest unused ID for user-added

actions instead of getting the next integer of the largest ID.



Bug: b/270973665

Test: manual test

Test: unit test

Change-Id: I20a4990895bf61f1af40e4413a1dbbf2e07f0f78

Reviewed-on: https://chromium-review.googlesource.com/c/chromium/src/+/4673705

entry.title: Revert "arc: Add dbc environment variable"
entry.content:
This reverts commit 1206550696892d710341cde0716494ad4ca413e3.



Reason for revert: #gardener suspect for failures on https://ci.chromium.org/ui/p/chrome/builders/ci/chromeos-eve-chrome/26509 in chrome_all_tast_tests arc.Boot.vm and ~14 other arc tests



FATAL chrome[28534:28534]: [thread_restrictions.cc(88)] Check failed: !GetBlockingDisallowedTls(). Function marked as blocking was called from a scope that disallows blocking



Original change's description:

entry.title: [remoting host][win] Enable MojoIpcz
entry.content:
This is yet another take of enabling MojoIpcz for Chromoting on

Windows. With this change, the daemon process will be the sole broker

in the process graph, and it will accept ChromotingHostServices

connections from client processes then forward the message pipe to the

network process for binding. With this approach, there is only one

connection point for mojo IPCs, and since the daemon process is highly

privileged, no tricks such as MOJO_SEND_INVITATION_FLAG_ELEVATED will

be needed.



This CL also gets rid of isolated connections in the code and updates

the comments, since isolated connections mean broker-to-broker

connections in MojoIpcz, which is totally different from what we try

to do.



Bug: 1378803

Change-Id: Ie618d2406a3049acac215f760605146a49983ce9

Reviewed-on: https://chromium-review.googlesource.com/c/chromium/src/+/4679202

entry.title: [dPWA] Use `ScopedRegistryUpdate` in favour of `WebAppRegistryUpdate`
entry.content:
By using `ScopedRegistryUpdate` instead of `WebAppRegistryUpdate`, we

ensure that we can never accidentally forget to commit the update, which

would crash all future updates.



This CL also refactors `WebAppSyncBridge::BeginUpdate` to return a

`ScopedRegistryUpdate` instead of a `WebAppRegistryUpdate`, which also

allows us to make `WebAppSyncBridge::CommitUpdate` private. As part of

this, the constructor of `ScopedRegistryUpdate` also becomes 'private'

(via `PassKey`).



Bug: 1444407

entry.title: Reland "[DBSC] Make it easier to test binding keys on Linux and Mac"
entry.content:
This is a reland of commit 964303340b500b4c1d2e10fa00c3a91f9a786149



Orignal CL wasn't the cause for the test failures:

https://crbug.com/1464248#c3



Original change's description:

> [DBSC] Make it easier to test binding keys on Linux and Mac

>

> //crypto currently has an UnexportableKeyProvider support on Windows

> only. Since most of the future developers work on Linux and Mac, it will

> be helpful to be able to test the feature on these platforms.

>

> To facilite local development, this CL adds a mock software-backed

> implementation of an UnexportableKeyProvider behind a feature flag. This

> feature flag is expected to never be shipped to end users.

>

> The flag is checked on the UnexportableKeyService level, so only

> DBSC-related code will switch to an insecure implementation.

>

entry.title: [emoji picker] Remove some un-necessary and probamatic afterNextRender callback.
entry.content:
In search view, if user clicks some category. We will go through `onCategoryButtonClick` method.



- 1), in `set('category', ...)` step, observer `onCategoryChanged` will be triggered and that registers a callback via `afterNextRender`.

- 2), in `onCategoryButtonClick` we register another callback which actually depends the completion of the first callback.



Thus, the click of category button actually fails (it only clears search text but cannot switch to group view).



We should remove the wrapper `afterNextRender` in category's observer.





Bug: b/291189941

Change-Id: I9fa668b06645d93672a1fa6880aafd62086131d9

entry.title: [UIA] Fix more ComPtr related memory leaks
entry.content:
This is a follow up to CL:4554261. The previous CL introduced a risky

pattern of returning a CComObj with a null reference count. This CL

replaced this pattern by instead accepting a ITextRangeProvider**

by parameter. This new solution forces callers to use the

ComPtr::operator& overload - which doesn't call AddRef - instead of

the ComPtr::operator= one - which does.

entry.title: Log warning during WebGL context loss workaround.
entry.content:
On dual-GPU macOS machines, WebGL 2.0 contexts may need to be lost if

the active GPU switches when using ANGLE's OpenGL backend. Log a

warning when this happens to explain to developers why it does.



Also stop dispatching these context losses when unnecessary - for

example, when using ANGLE's Metal backend, or when on machines without

dual GPUs.



Bug: 1465065

entry.title: Use less confusing URL for same-document navigations to blocked URLs.
entry.content:
When Chrome receives a navigation request from the renderer, it

validates the target URL by passing it through `FilterURL()`. This

prevents scenarios like a malicious non-WebUI renderer navigating to a

WebUI URL: an untrustworthy renderer should not be able to trigger a

navigation to a privileged WebUI URL.



Independently of this, Chrome enforces a max limit of 2*1024*1024 ASCII

characters when sending URLs over IPC. URLs over this limit are silently

deserialized as an empty GURL.



Combined with the `FilterURL()` check in navigation mentioned above,

this means that navigations to URLs that exceed the length limit are

blocked and rewritten to about:blank#blocked.



For cross-document navigations, the result is fairly innocuous, if

somewhat unexpected: a navigation to an excessively long URL simply

turns into a cross-document navigation to about:blank#blocked.



For a same-document navigation, this leads to strangeness though:

same-document navigations complete synchronously in the renderer and are

asynchronously reported to the browser. Thus, the URL in the omnibox

changes to about:blank#blocked, but since the browser has no way of

reporting this failure to the renderer, the browser process and renderer

process end up disagreeing about the current document's URL.



While it would be ideal to reject such same-document navigations as

invalid in the renderer process, behaviour in this area is inconsistent

across different navigation APIs and different browsers. Instead, this

CL takes a less ambitious approach: when the renderer performs a

same-document navigation to a blocked URL, the browser simply uses the

current document's URL as the target URL instead of about:blank#blocked.



While not wholly accurate (after all, there is still a state mismatch

between the browser and the renderer), it is a bit less misleading

overall and reduces the URL spoof potential of this weird state.



Additional details exploring potential followups are available at

https://docs.google.com/document/d/1H522TDBEDqfFgXOdFw5FOVotWlOCFOcXPhUWxK7Uu1U/edit



Bug: 1451592

Change-Id: Iafed3aec01f2f33dd628c29c76eec0790e355040

Reviewed-on: https://chromium-review.googlesource.com/c/chromium/src/+/4624360

Commit-Queue: Daniel Cheng

Reviewed-by: Charlie Reis

entry.title: Split course work cache for student and teacher glanceables
entry.content:
Splits GlanceablesClassroomClientImpl::course_work_ into two maps - one

for teacher role, and one for student role. This allow clearing

information about inactive courses from the map. With a single map,

clearing inactive courses where the user is a teacher risks clearing

information about courses where the user is a student.



Given that now methods to fetch course work or student submissions take

a reference to the target course work map as an argument, the callbacks

no longer need to return the update map as their argument - tests can

just verify the state of the course work per course map pass as an

argument to the fetch method (the "returned" callback argument was used

in tests only).



BUG=b:283371186

entry.title: Use Primary Monitor Refresh Rate as Interval on Windows SV3+
entry.content:
On Windows SV3+ builds DWM will allow per-monitor refresh rates which

means that the interval reported by DwmGetCompositionTimingInfo may no

longer align with the Primary Monitor.



On devices with multi-mon setups where the Primary monitor's refresh

rate is slower than another display on the system then the calculated

interval will not match with the actual duration of our WaitForVBlank

on the primary display.



This can have cascading effects on VSync listeners as calls like

OnBeginFrame cadence will not match with the specified interval. As

an example for the VideoFrameSubmitter this can result in dropped

frames over time as frame intervals will be missed & best matches

will be skipped.



Bug: 1456399

Change-Id: I846785b032af2c18f321fc70b9a85bc81d045116

Reviewed-on: https://chromium-review.googlesource.com/c/chromium/src/+/4638125

Reviewed-by: Rafael Cintron

Commit-Queue: William Carr

Cr-Commit-Position: refs/heads/main@{#1171416}

entry.title: crosint: Add prototype test that toggles Bluetooth from ash UI
entry.content:
Use Kombucha to write an interactive_ui_test that opens quick settings,

clicks the Bluetooth feature tile toggle button to disable Bluetooth,

and verifies via D-Bus that bluez has powered off the adapter.



The test uses Bluez instead of Floss since it's just a prototype. The

test can run in the linux-chromeos "emulator" (in interactive_ui_tests)

and on real hardware (in chromeos_integration_tests), so add it to

both targets. It cannot run in a VM, since ChromeOS VM images don't

support Bluetooth.



This test is similar to the existing ChromeOS Tast test

bluetooth.ToggleBluetoothFromQuickSettings.



Bug: 1464750

Test: interactive_ui_tests

Test: out_dedede/Release/bin/run_chromeos_integration_tests --board=dedede --device=localhost:2222 --enable-pixel-output-in-tests --test-launcher-interactive --user-data-dir=/tmp/udd --disable-mojo-broker --gtest_filter=Bluetooth*

entry.title: Revert "Reland "PreloadingDevTools: Disable prerendering for clients other than DevTools frontend""
entry.content:
This reverts commit b122b241a6953480e212d08bbe5cf943273b55c9.



Reason for revert: still suspect for flakes in prerender.js; see https://crbug.com/1465610



Original change's description:

> Reland "PreloadingDevTools: Disable prerendering for clients other than DevTools frontend"

>

> This reverts commit 1d662ac2d1de7a911afab7420cb832b4b31284c9.

>

> Original change's description:

> > Revert "PreloadingDevTools: Disable prerendering for clients other than DevTools frontend"

> >

> > This reverts commit 9d392f330f25bce3f6fc8c2b0b927e02a7bd28c5.

> >

> > Reason for revert: Suspect for making

> > http/tests/inspector-protocol/tracing/prerender.js flaky on Mac:

> > https://ci.chromium.org/ui/p/chromium/builders/ci/Mac10.15%20Tests

> > https://ci.chromium.org/ui/p/chromium/builders/ci/Mac10.15%20Tests/39245/overview

> >

> > Original change's description:

> > > PreloadingDevTools: Disable prerendering for clients other than DevTools frontend

> > >

> > > Prerendering introduced switching of FrameTreeNodes in the browser side

> > > and frame targets in the CDP client side. If a CDP client unaware of

> > > this logic and a prerendered page activated, it will cause unexpected

> > > behaviors. For example, Puppeteer loses control. To mitigate this, this

> > > CL disables prerendering if a target without tab target support is

> > > attached. For more details, see [1].

> > >

> > > [1] https://docs.google.com/document/d/12HVmFxYj5Jc-eJr5OmWsa2bqTJsbgGLKI6ZIyx0_wpA

> > >

> > > Bug: 1440085

> > > Change-Id: I80bf9234b60722112baf21c4fa2ee1f0d0cb3221

> > > Reviewed-on: https://chromium-review.googlesource.com/c/chromium/src/+/4495911

entry.title: [Metadata][Metrics] Do not log issuer specific metrics for cloud token metadata
entry.content:
Currently cards that have an issuer id, but are not part of the issuer

integration will log histogram like

"Autofill.CreditCard..ShownWithMetadata" with an empty issuer id.



Issuer id is not tied to metadata, so we should not rely on it to log

metrics. For the metadata project, we're interested in issuer metrics

for only issuers that have direct integration.



It is possible that cards that get metadata from network integration

(cloud token metadata) also have an issuer id. Do not log issuer metrics

for such cards.



Bug: 1464789

entry.title: Ensure proper Actions handling when no tabs are available.
entry.content:
The origin of this scenario is somewhat unknown, but according to

the crash/ site, it is possible for the user to have an interactable

Omnibox that is not attached to a valid tab.



This change ensures we are always checking whether Tab is available

before evaluating if it is an incognito and/or interactable one.

entry.title: multipaste: Create ClipboardHistoryUrlTitleFetcher abstraction
entry.content:
This CL introduces the ClipboardHistoryUrlTitleFetcher, which queries

the active user's browsing history whenever the user copies text. A

subsequent CL will add logic so that if the text is determined to be the

URL for a page the user has visited, that page title will be displayed

underneath the URL in the clipboard history menu. This UI change will

help users more easily identify the URLs in their clipboard history.
